papers Levy Citizen Marion Citizen Riverland News Wakulla News Fun & Games Comics Puzzles Share This Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Boomtown Days celebrating 50 years SPECIAL TO THE CHRONICLE Apr 12, 2023 Apr 12, 2023 0 1 min to read Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Two cowboys argue during Kidd Carson’s Wild West Show during Boomtown Days 2022. The cowboys performed four shows for the crowds during the festival. Chronicle file photo Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save There will be plenty to see and do in Dunnellon on Saturday from 9 a.m to 5 p.m. at the annual Boomtown celebration. Antique cars, classic cars, crafters, cowboys and festival foods, including beer and wine, are all part of the fun lined up for the festival. The festival is organized by the Dunnellon Chamber and Business Association. Judy Terwilliger, executive director for the DCBA, said she was expecting to have more than 100 craft booths and 15 food trucks set up along West Pennsylvania Avenue in Dunnellon’s Historic District. Cowboy shows will be staged throughout the late morning and early afternoon behind the Rainbow Springs Art in Dunnellon building. Music is always a big part of the festivities, and this year is no exception. Jake White starts the lineup at 10:30 a.m., followed by R-Style at 12:30 p.m. and the Keith Caton Blues Band at 2:30. Thirty-six contestants are vying for seven different titles in pageants throughout the day. Those selected will include Boomtown Baby, Tiny Miss Dunnellon, Little Miss Dunnellon, Duchess of Dunnellon, Junior Princess of the Rainbow and Queen of the Rainbow. Pageants start at 9 a.m. and continue till 12:40 p.m. for the Queen of the Rainbow contest. Boomtown is a celebration of the discovery of phosphate in Dunnellon and the subsequent “boom” that followed as those seeking to get rich flocked to the area. This year’s event is the 50th anniversary of Boomtown. Boomtown Days: Pies, blues and bandits News Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals LOCAL Boomtown Days: Pies, blues and bandits Six Gun Territory crew to fire up Dunnellon's big party Dave Schlenker dave.schlenker@ocala.com The annual Boomtown Days festival is a nod to Dunnellon's phosphate boom in the 1800s. It has become one of Marion County's biggest spring events, a vast family street party that spreads out over multiple blocks and attracts 8,000 people or more to the otherwise small river city. This year's festival will fill the city's historic district with about 100 vendors selling everything from plants to art to cowboy hats. There will be a kids area and crafts and pageants. There will be performances by blues man Keith Caton and rock band Final Note. There also will be a classic car show with 80 vehicles or more. And new this year: a pie-eating contest hosted by Dunnellon's Harmony Preschool. "This year we wanted to make it an old-town country fair," said Julie Mancini, executive director of the Dunnellon Chamber and Business Association. Looking for a free mini puzzle? Play the USA TODAY Quick Cross now. But this old town also will be crawling with outlaws, lawmen and can-can dancers. Sometimes, that is not a healthy mix, especially around the festival's Boomtown Saloon. Therefore, amid the spring fun, crafts, games and food, there likely will be some trash-talking cowboys roaming Boomtown's streets. And that trash talk will boil over into a field near Pennsylvania Avenue and Cedar Street, where carefully choreographed Wild West shootouts will settle the disputes and provide some business for Digger the undertaker. That's right, the Six Gun Territory crew is back at Boomtown Days this year, celebrating not only the city's heritage but also its own. The pretend gunfights, tough talk and can-can dances are ripped right from the dusty streets of the long-defunct Six Gun Territory theme park in Ocala. Many cast members from the park — the people who played outlaws, good guys and can-can dancers — reunited in 2015 at Kirby Family Farm in Williston, where they still get together each year for public reunions with shootouts. But the movement has grown and attracted new can-can dancers and gunslingers. The current crew started appearing at Boomtown Days in 2016, staging saloon-soaked brawls amid the festival trappings. Their presence is a bit of a festival throwback, as well, because many of the cast members used to make appearances at Boomtown Days decades ago when the park was in his full swing, said Jim Pierce, who worked as a gunslinger at Six Gun in 1960s through early 1970s. He well remembers suiting up in his Six Gun gear and mingling with the Boomtown Days crowds in the 1970s. These days, though, the Six Gun players step it up up a notch, bringing the Wild West spittle to the streets and then squaring off for the shootout in the staging area. There will be up to 50 people in the Six Gun delegation at Boomtown Days on Saturday, Pierce said. That will include good guys, bad guys, can-can dancers and support staff. Of the cast of gunslingers, six or more — Pierce included — will be original from the old park. There also are several original dancers from the old park in the current line-up of can-can dancers. "They say they are the can't-can't dancers," Pierce said. Boomtown Days What: Annual family festival celebrating Dunnellon's history When: 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. Saturday Where: Downtown Dunnellon, off Pennsylvania Avenue in the historic district Admission: Free; vendors available (489-2320) Boomtown Days Pancake Breakfast and Six Gun Shootout When: 7:30-9 a.m. Friday Where: Historic Train Depot, 12061 S. Williams St., Dunnellon Cost: $6 (489-2320) Careers Staff Directory Accessibility Sitemap Legals Public notice certification Our Ethical Principles USA TODAY Network Style Guide Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Advertiser Acceptance Policy Terms of Service Privacy Policy California Notice at Collection Your Privacy Choices Contact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Buy and Sell Licensing & Reprints Help Center Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give Feedback Subscribe Today Newsletters Facebook X Instagram eNewspaper Archives Jobs Real Estate Classifieds Shopping 10BEST LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions © 2025 www.ocala.com. Dunnellon Boomtown Days News Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals NEWS Dunnellon Boomtown Days Dunnellon pays homage to heritage BY MONICA BRYANT STAFF WRITER B oomTown Days are back. Each year in April, the Dunnellon Area Chamber of Commerce traditional celebration turns back the hands of time to pay tribute to the city's primitive beginnings in phosphate mining. The 3-day festival, which celebrates more than 30 years of Dunnellon's heritage, draws nearly 10,000 people to the area to remember the era when the town was discovered and boomed during the 1890s. "It's an effort to bring Dunnellon to the notice of people in Florida," said Don Koppler, executive director of the Chamber. "Hey, we're over here, come find us, come shop and visit." To make the annual tradition more appealing, this year Koppler added a contest to name the mascots - two cartoon armadillos that symbolize the discovery of phosphate and the resulting mining industry. "We're trying to bring back the old small town spirit by having the mascots as a conversation piece," Koppler said. "We're attempting to refocus on the phosphate industry that was the start of our boom that made us. Boom Town will be branded with our armadillos." The festival kicks off today with a community breakfast hosted by the Front Porch Restaurant and Pie Shop at the Dunnellon Bingo Hall at7:30 a.m. Prizes will be awarded for best costume by individuals, and local businesses will be judged for best decoration and employee costume. The two names for the BoomTown Days mascot contest will be announced, the BoomTown mayor will be elected and the winning tickets for the Chinese Auction will be drawn. The continental buffet costs $3.50. Later that evening, Southeast Pride, the Navy's Rock Band, will host a free community concert from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m. at Ernie Mills Park. The music is Anna Bell Dobbs' favorite part. She said she's been attending the festival for about 10 years with her husband, Olin, and they enjoy walking around, seeing everybody and having a good time. "Every year we're here we know more people," she said. "It shows people what's really here. We talk to people who come from St. Petersburg or over in The Villages, and they can't believe what we have." The event boasts having something for everyone. Koppler said last year the Heritage Park area, which featured American Indian storytellers, dancers and miniature horses, drew more people, so they expanded it. But the main attraction is the arts and crafts. He said people always comment on the quality of the vendors. "It's just full of all kinds of crafts. Really, really good crafts," said Barbara Walker. "Not only the amount of crafts they have, but the quality of them is just wonderful." New this year is the addition of the Florida Cracker Cowman's Camp. The Dunnellon Women's Club will mark 82 years of community service by dressing in period costumes and handing out homemade cookies. Pet adoptions are available through the Humane Society of Marion County. Pony rides, a petting zoo, a rock climbing wall and rug weaving, spinning wheel and canoe construction demonstrations, also will be included. The BoomTown Mayor will cut the ribbon marking the festival's official opening at 10 a.m. on Saturday. Winners of the Little Miss and Mister Dunnellon pageant will be announced at 3 p.m. Almost 100 arts and crafts vendors will fill West Pennsylvania Avenue and display their wares, and Capt. Mike's Lazy River Cruises will offer 45-minute pontoon boat rides for $10. On Sunday, the winners of the Queen of the Rainbow River pageant will be crowned, and the Lions Club will host its 26th Annual Auto Show in Heritage Park throughout the day. "It's a lot of fun," Walker said about the festival. "It just gets better every year. "You walk around the streets, meet your neighbors and have a hot dog. It's just a good time," she said. The festival is from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. Free parking is available at Dunnellon Middle School. Proceeds help fund chamber projects such as Boom Town, Jazz up, Home for the Holidays, the Christmas Parade or to promote the Dunnellon Area. Monica Bryant covers State Road 200 and the Dunnellon Area. She can be reached at monica.bryant@starbanner.com or 867-4131.
